questions.text: A 4-month-old infant was brought to the emergency department. On asking the guardian, they gave the history of fall at home. he was seen crying persistently. On examination, the infant had multiple bruises. After performing a skeletal survey, multiple metaphyseal fractures were found. Which of the other following findings is more likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Metaphyseal injuries, or Corner or Bucket Handle fractures, are significant indicators of physical abuse in infants, particularly in those under 12 months who are nonmobile.

These injuries occur due to shearing forces from violent shaking or handling, leading to microfractures in the metaphysis, particularly in the primary spongiosa.

These fractures are typically asymptomatic and not easily detectable through clinical examination.

They are most commonly found in the distal femur, tibia, and proximal humerus, and can be present unilaterally or bilaterally. Recognizing these radiographic patterns is crucial for identifying potential cases of abuse and ensuring appropriate intervention.


KEY TAKE AWAY:

Radiographic Findings:

  1. Bucket-Handle Fracture: Appears as a thin wafer of bone that is separated from the metaphysis, with a thicker periphery.
  2. Corner Fracture: Characterized by a thick rim of bone, representing a localized injury.
  3. Mixed Appearance: A thin disk with a thick rim, suggesting varying degrees of injury.

OTHER OPTIONS:

COLLES' FRACRURE: Dorsal displacement of distal fragment of the fracture. it is an extra articular fracture.


Torus fractures, also known as buckle fractures, are incomplete fractures of the shaft of a long bone that is characterized by bulging of the cortex.


A greenstick fracture is a type of broken bone where one side of the bone cracks but doesn't break all the way through.


NOTE:

  • Buckle Fracture - torus
  • Bucket handle fracture - metaphyseal corner fractures

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture in the X-Ray given below:
questions.solution:
Pediatric fractures.

Greenstick Fracture

  • A greenstick fracture is a progression beyond a buckle injury.
  • It involves buckling on the concave side and also a partial interruption of the cortex on the convex side, resembling a bent branch.
  • This type of fracture typically occurs in younger children, reflecting the pliability of their bones.

Buckle (Torus) Fracture

  • Buckle fractures occur when elastic and plastic injuries lead to localized buckling of the cortex and periosteum on the concave sideof the bone.
  • This type of injury is often seen in pediatric patients and represents a relatively stable form of fracture, with no complete break in the bone.

Bucket handle Fracture

Occur due to shearing forces from violent shaking or handling, leading to microfractures in the metaphysis.

Nightstick Fracture

This is isolated fractures of the ulna, typically transverse and located in the mid-diaphysis and usually resulting from a direct blow. It is a characteristic defensive fracture when the patient tries to ward off an overhead blow from an assailant.


KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: Which of the following bone is not a common site of avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
Osteonecrosis is a generic term referring to the ischemic death of the constituents of bone. It has a wide variety of causes and can affect nearly any bone in the body.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Classification by eponymous names

  • Buchman Disease: Iliac crest
  • Burns Disease: Distal ulna
  • Freiberg Infraction: Head of the second metatarsal
  • Friedrich Disease: Medial clavicle
  • Haas Disease: Humeral head
  • Kienböck Disease: Lunate
  • Köhler Disease: Patella or navicular (children)
  • Kümmell Disease: Vertebral body
  • Legg-Calvé-Perthes Disease: Femoral head
  • Panner Disease: Capitellum of the humerus
  • Pierson Disease: Symphysis pubis
  • Preiser Disease: Scaphoid
  • Sever Disease: Calcaneal epiphysis

questions.text: A patient had a history of fall. Now he presents with difficulty walking and deformity. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Malunion occurs when a fracture heals in a non-anatomical position, potentially leading to functional impairment and aesthetic concerns.

Causes of Malunion

  1. Inaccurate Reduction: Improper alignment during the initial treatment, whether through closed or open methods.
  2. Loss of Reduction: Displacement of the fracture fragments after initial alignment, often due to inadequate fixation.
  3. Inadequate Immobilization: Insufficient stabilization during the healing process, which can allow for movement at the fracture site.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option a. Fracture non-union refers to the failure of normal fracture healing processes, characterized by the absence of healing for at least three months after a minimum of nine months since the initial injury.

Option d.

Fracture healing is a complex biological process that occurs in several stages: inflammation, repair, and remodeling.

  • Initially, a hematoma forms at the fracture site,
  • formation of a fibrocartilaginous callus as soft tissue repair begins.
  • This is replaced by a bony callus as new bone form.
  • Finally, the remodeling phase reshapes and strengthens the bone, restoring its original structure and function.
  • Factors such as age, nutrition, and blood supply can influence the healing process

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A patient had a history of fall and as a result he sustained fracture. He was undergoing treatment for the same however complained of persisting pain at the site. An x ray was done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fracture non-union refers to the failure of normal fracture healing processes, characterized by the absence of healing for at least three months after a minimum of nine months since the initial injury.

Types of Fracture Non-Union

  1. Hypertrophic Non-Union:
    • Characteristics: Abundant callus formation.
    • Imaging Features: Radiolucent line at the non-union site indicating unmineralized fibrocartilage.
  2. Oligotrophic Non-Union:
    • Characteristics: Little or no callus formation.
    • Imaging Features: Diastasis (separation) at the fracture site.
  3. Atrophic Non-Union:
    • Characteristics: Bony surfaces partially resorbed with no callus formation; often associated with osteopenia.
    • Imaging Features: Sclerotic avascular bone segments and segmental bone loss.
  4. Infected Non-Union:
    • Characteristics: Presence of infection at the fracture site.
    • Imaging Features: Osteolysis, osteopenia, sclerotic avascular bone segments, and segmental bone loss.
  5. Synovial Pseudoarthrosis:
    • Characteristics: Variable appearance depending on the type of non-union.
    • Imaging Features: May exhibit features of hypertrophic, oligotrophic, or atrophic non-union.

Option b: Malunion occurs when a fracture heals in a non-anatomical position, potentially leading to functional impairment and aesthetic concerns.

Option d.

Fracture healing is a complex biological process that occurs in several stages: inflammation, repair, and remodeling.

  • Initially, a hematoma forms at the fracture site,
  • formation of a fibrocartilaginous callus as soft tissue repair begins.
  • This is replaced by a bony callus as new bone form.
  • Finally, the remodeling phase reshapes and strengthens the bone, restoring its original structure and function.
  • Factors such as age, nutrition, and blood supply can influence the healing process

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
KEY TAKE AWAY:

Non articular fracture of wrist:

Dorsal displacement = colles' fracture

Ventral displacement = smith fracture

questions.text: A young patient presented with pain in the legs since 6 months. The pain worsened at night. On doing an Xray the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteoid osteoma is a small, benign vascular osteoblastic tumor often presenting with a characteristic clinical picture of night pain, typically relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Location:

  • Most commonly found in the appendicular skeleton, particularly:
    • Tibia
    • Femur
  • Usually located in the diaphysis or metaphysis.

Imaging Features:

  • X-rays:
    • Can show reactive changes that may obscure the nidus.
  • CT Scan:
    • Displays a round or oval nidus of soft-tissue density with central dense mineralization.
    • Vascular Groove Sign:Appears as thin channels in the thickened bone surrounding the nidus.
  • MRI:
    • Shows heterogeneous low to intermediate signal intensity (SI) on T1-weighted images.
    • Variable SI on STIR and T2-weighted images, depending on sclerosis/mineralization.
    • The nidus enhances strongly on post-contrast studies.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option a: Osteochondroma, also known as cartilage-capped exostosis, is a true neoplasm that can arise in various contexts, including after total body radiotherapy, Salter-Harris fractures, and surgical procedures.


Option c: Chondrosarcoma is a cartilaginous origin tumor. It is malignant neoplasm.


Option d: Osteosarcoma is a complex and aggressive bone tumor, primarily affecting younger individuals. It is bone forming tumor. Xray showing sunburst appearance.


KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling around the knee joint. It was non warm and non-tender. There was no difficulty in moving the legs. On doing an Xray, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteochondroma, also known as cartilage-capped exostosis, is a true neoplasm that can arise in various contexts, including after total body radiotherapy, Salter-Harris fractures, and surgical procedures.

Common Locations:

  • Long Bones: Most commonly affected, especially around the knee (∼40% of cases).
    • Specific Sites:
      • Distal femur
      • Proximal humerus
      • Proximal tibia
      • Proximal femur
    • Flat Bones: Less frequently affected, including the ilium and scapula.

Lesion Types:

  • Pedunculated Osteochondroma:
    • Has a thin stalk that typically points away from the adjacent joint.
  • Sessile Osteochondroma:
    • Arises from a broad base.

Location:

  • Typically located in the metaphysisof the affected bone.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Patients may experience mechanical issues such as:
    • Enlarging mass
    • Pressure on surrounding structures (muscles, vessels)
    • Rarely, fracture of the bony stem.

Imaging Features:

  • Diagnostic Criteria:
    • Continuity between the medullary cavity of the osteochondroma and that of the underlying bone is essential for diagnosis.
  • Best Imaging Modalities:
    • CT Scan: Provides detailed images to confirm continuity.
    • MRI: Optimal for demonstrating the cartilage cap.
      • The cartilage cap is best visualized onaxial proton density-weighted (PDW) or T2-weighted fat-saturated (FSE) sequences.
      • The hyperintense cartilage cap contrasts with adjacent iso-/hypointense muscle.

Cartilage Cap Thickness:

  • In children: Typically measures 1-3 cm.
  • In adults: Should not exceed 2 cm; typically measures only a few millimeters.

Option b: Osteoid osteoma is a small, benign vascular osteoblastic tumor often presenting with a characteristic clinical picture of night pain, typically relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Given image shows CT finding - nidus.


Option c: Chondrosarcoma is a cartilage forming tumor and shows ring and arcs calcification.

Option d: Osteosarcoma is a bone forming tumor and shows sun ray appearance.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Osteochondroma is a benign cartilage tumor.
  • Located at metaphysis of bone.
  • Cartilage gap measuring more than 2 cm on MRI indicates malignancy.
  • Most common involved is around knee.

questions.text: A young patient presented to you with pain around the shoulder. On examination you notice a swelling. You ordered an Xray. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma is a complex and aggressive bone tumor, primarily affecting younger individuals.

Key Features of Osteosarcoma:

  1. Radiographic Findings:
    • Bone Destruction: Medullary and cortical bone involvement is common.
    • Transition Zone: A wide zone of transition with permeative or moth-eaten patterns is typical.
    • Periosteal Reactions: Aggressive reactions, including sunburst patterns and Codman triangles, are notable.
    • Soft-Tissue Mass: Often observed accompanying the bone lesion.
    • Tumor Matrix: Variability in ossification and calcification reflects tumor characteristics.
  2. Imaging Modalities:
    • Conventional X-rays: Crucial for initial diagnosis and assessing the characteristic features.
    • CT Scans: Primarily used for biopsy guidance and staging.
    • MRI: Essential for detailed local staging, especially for evaluating intraosseous extension and soft-tissue involvement, aiding in decisions for limb-sparing procedures.

Metastatic Potential:

  • Osteosarcoma has a high tendency for lung and lymph node metastasis, with the potential for ossification in metastases.
  • It's important to monitor for complications such as spontaneous pneumothorax in cases of lung metastases.

Option a. Osteochondroma is a benign exostosis of the bone with cartilaginous cap.

Option b. Osteoid osteoma (OO) is a small, benign vascular osteoblastic tumor often presenting with a characteristic clinical picture of night pain, typically relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Option c. Chondrosarcoma is malignant cartilaginous tumor.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

choices.text: Fallen leaf sign - Aneurysmal bone cyst
Fallen leaf sign - Simple bone cyst

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with pain in the arm. An Xray is shown in the image below. What is the sign and diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Definition: Simple bone cyst (SBC), or unicameral bone cyst.

Age Group: Common in individuals aged 5 to 15 years; <15% in those over 20.

Common Locations:

  • Proximal humerus: >60% of cases.
  • Proximal femur: ~30% of cases.

Initial Location: Located in the proximal metaphysis of the humerus or femur.

Progression: Cysts progress toward the diaphysis with skeletal growth, often reaching mid-diaphysis by healing.

Appearance:

  • Centrally located in the shaft.
  • Symmetrical bone expansion and cortical thinning.
  • Typically, 6 to 8 cm in size.
  • Narrow zone of transition with a thin sclerotic margin.

Radiological Features:

  • Apparent trabeculation is common.
  • No periosteal reaction unless a fracture occurs (can lead to "fallen fragment" sign).

MRI Characteristics:

  • Fluid content with low-to-intermediate signal intensity on T1-weighted images.
  • Marked hyperintensity on T2-weighted and STIR images.
  • "Rising bubble" sign: locule of gas/vacuum phenomenon in cyst with a pathological fracture.

Contrast Enhancement: Rim enhancement noted following contrast administration.

OTHER OPTIONS

Aneurysmal bone cyst


KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with pain and swelling around the wrist joint. On doing an Xray the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant cell tumor (GCT) is an aggressive benign neoplasm, accounting for about 20% of benign bone tumors.

Association: Multifocal, metachronous GCTs may be linked to hyperparathyroidism.

Common Locations:

  • Subarticular or subchondral regions of long bones.
  • Most frequent sites:
    • Knee (distal femur/proximal tibia): 55%
    • Distal radius: 10%
    • Proximal humerus: 6%

Characteristics:

  • Classically appears as a subarticular, eccentric, lytic lesion.
  • Geographic, non-sclerotic margin.
  • Typically measures 5-7 cm in size.
  • Apparent trabeculation and cortical expansion are common.
  • Periosteal reaction seen in 10%-15% of cases, often indicating healing of a fracture.

Cortical Involvement: Up to 50% may show cortical destruction with extra-osseous extension.

MRI Features:

  • Iso- or hypointense on T1-weighted images.
  • Heterogeneous hyperintensity on STIR images.
  • Areas of hyperintensity on T1-weighted images may indicate subacute hemorrhage.

Option a: Simple bone cyst occurs in the pediatric age group. Fallen fragment sign is seen in it.

Option b: Aneurysmal bone cyst is a multiloculated cystic lesion with air fluid levels within it. IT is seen in immature skeletons. Unfused epiphysis rules out GCT making ABC more probable.

However, GCT is an epiphyseal tumor whereas, ABC is metaphyseal tumor.

Option d: Osteoma is a bone forming benign tumor.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Giant cell tumor is benign, but tumor of bone.
  • Typically, located in epiphysis of the bone.
  • Histology shows giant cells and mononuclear cells.
  • Giant cells are not malignantwhile mononuclear cells are malignant.

questions.text: A patient presented with deformity of the lower limbs. He complained of occasional pain in the limbs. On doing an Xray, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fibrous dysplasia (FD) is a developmental abnormality where defective osteoblastic differentiation leads to replacement of normal bone marrow with fibrous-osseous tissue.

Forms:

  • Monostotic: Occurs in 70%-85% of cases.
  • Polyostotic: Involves multiple bones.

Symptoms: Usually painless unless a fracture occurs.

Radiological Appearance:

  • Presents as a geographic lesion that may cause bone expansion and deformity.
  • Shows diffuse ground-glass matrix mineralization.
  • Characteristic thick sclerotic margin (the "rind" sign).
  • Purely lytic lesions may indicate extensive cystic degeneration.

Affected Regions: Typically affects the meta diaphyseal region in long bones.

Periosteal Reaction: Not typically seen in the absence of a fracture.

Characteristic Findings:

  • Varus deformity of the proximal femur, known as "shepherd's crook" deformity, is a late finding and may be associated with a pathological fracture.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Associated Syndromes:

  • McCune-Albright Syndrome:
    • Characterized by polyostotic FD (typically unilateral).
    • Ipsilateral café-au-lait spots.
    • Endocrine disturbances, often precocious puberty in girls.
  • Mazabraud Syndrome:
    • Involves polyostotic FD and associated with atrial myxoma.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Thalassemia - hair on end appearance
  • Paget's disease - blade of grass appearance
  • Fibrous dysplasia - Shepherd crook deformity
  • Multiple myeloma - punched out lyric lesion

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the heel region. On doing an Xray the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Intraosseous lipoma (IOL) is a benign bone tumor that typically arises in the medulla and can cause bone expansion.

Features:

  • Can lead to endosteal scalloping, trabecular resorption, fat necrosis, cyst formation, granulation tissue, calcification, and reactive new bone formation.
  • Appearance can vary, sometimes resembling a cyst or fibrous dysplasia (FD).
  • commonly presenting in the fourth and fifth decades of life.

Common Locations:

  • Primarily affects the lower limb.
  • Predilection for the calcaneus and femur.
  • Proximal humerus is also a common site.

Radiographic Appearance:

  • Appears as a well-defined radiolucent lesion with a sclerotic margin.
  • May show calcification due to fat necrosis.

Imaging Techniques:

  • CT: Shows intralesional fat density, a calcified rim, and any intra-lesional trabeculation or ossification.
  • MRI: Confirms the fatty nature of the matrix and can display areas of cystic change, granulation tissue, or calcification.

Option b: Osteoid osteoma (OO) is a small, benign vascular osteoblastic tumor often presenting with a characteristic clinical picture of night pain, typically relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Option c: Osteosarcoma is a bone forming malignant tumor and shows sun ray appearance.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A 3-year-old male patient presented with pain in the lower limb and weakness. On doing an Xray the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ewing sarcoma and PNET are now recognized as part of the same family of tumors, which also includes adult neuroblastoma and Askin tumor.

Symptoms:

  • Present with localized pain and swelling.
  • Systemic symptoms such as pyrexia and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) may mimic infection and indicate disseminated disease.

Radiographic Features:

  • Appears as a permeative destructive lesion with a wide zone of transition.
  • Aggressive lesions can be challenging to identify on radiographs, especially at early presentation.

Soft Tissue Involvement: Soft-tissue extension is evident in approximately 80% of cases.

Periosteal Reactions:

  • Classic multilamellar ("onion skin") periosteal reaction is uncommon.
  • Interrupted periosteal reaction (Codman angle) observed in 27% of cases.
  • Vertical "hair-on-end" or spiculated periosteal reaction is characteristic.
  • "Saucerization" of the outer cortex with a soft-tissue mass may represent a rarer periosteal variant.

MRI Findings:

  • Accurately defines medullary infiltration and soft-tissue extension.
  • Shows intermediate signal intensity (SI) on T1-weighted images.
  • Displays intermediate to high SI on T2-weighted and STIR sequences relative to skeletal muscle.

Metastasis:

  • Skip metastases identified in about 12% of cases.
  • Distant metastases (less than 20%) may occur in lungs and bones, potentially visible on initial imaging for surgical staging.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presented with hip joint pain and swelling. On doing an Xray the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumor.

  1. Classification:
    • Central Chondrosarcoma: Arises within medullary bone.
    • Peripheral Chondrosarcoma: Arises from the surface of bone.
  2. Age of Onset:
    • Most patients are over 50 years old, with peak incidence in the fifth to seventh decades.
    • Secondary chondrosarcoma typically presents at a younger age, around the fourth and fifth decades.
  3. Radiographic Features:
    • Appears as a lytic lesion.
    • Well-defined in low-grade cases; progressively ill-defined in higher-grade cases.
    • Chondroid calcification visible in 75% of cases, described as ring-and-arc, punctate, stippled, or popcorn-like.
  4. Imaging Techniques:
    • CT: Helpful in identifying occult chondroid matrix not visible on radiographs.
    • MRI: Shows a hyperintense multilocular pattern on fluid-sensitive sequences, reflecting high water content of cartilage, with interspersed foci of low signal intensity (SI) on all pulse sequences indicating chondroid calcification.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A 3-year-old patient presented with bleeding gums and easy bruising of the skin. On doing a platelet count, everything was found to be normal. The treating physician then decided to do an Xray of the limbs which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), leading to increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis, osteoporosis, and delayed wound healing.

Radiographic Features

Pediatric

  • Generalized Osteopenia: Reduced bone density throughout the skeleton.
  • Cortical Thinning: "Pencil-point" appearance of the cortex due to reduced bone mass.
  • Periosteal Reaction: Thickening or irregularity of the periosteum due to subperiosteal hemorrhage.
  • Scorbutic Rosary: Expansion at the costochondral junctions, resembling a rosary, similar to the rachitic rosary seen in rickets.
  • Hemarthrosis: Presence of blood in the joint cavities.
  • Wimberger Ring Sign: Circular, opaque shadow around the epiphyseal centers of ossification, indicative of bleeding.
  • Frankel Line: Dense zone of provisional calcification visible on radiographs.
  • Trümmerfeld Zone: Lucent metaphyseal band beneath the Frankel line.
  • Pelkan Spur: Metaphyseal spurs resulting from cupping of the metaphysis due to healing of microfractures.

Adults

  • Osteopenia: Reduced bone density.
  • Pathological Fractures: Fractures occurring with minimal or no trauma, related to weakened bone structure.

Option c: Fluorosis is a condition caused by excessive fluoride exposure, often leading to dental and skeletal changes.


Skeletal Fluorosis: In cases of skeletal fluorosis, X-rays may reveal increased bone density and changes in bone architecture, including thickening of the cortical bone and calcification of ligaments and tendons.

Radiographic Appearance: The presence of "ground glass" appearance in bones can be seen, indicating a loss of normal trabecular pattern, often associated with advanced fluorosis.

Option d: Acromegaly is a hormonal disorder caused by excess growth hormone, often due to a pituitary adenoma.

  • Skeletal Changes: X-rays may show enlarged bones, particularly of the hands, feet, and skull. Characteristic findings include thickened cortices and increased bone density.
  • Pituitary Imaging: MRI is the preferred modality for assessing pituitary adenomas. It typically reveals an enlarged pituitary gland with a mass effect, which may displace the optic chiasm.
  • Facial Changes: CT or MRI may demonstrate features such as an enlarged mandible, enlarged nasal bones, and changes in the soft tissue of the face, contributing to the characteristic appearance of acromegaly.

KEY TAKE AWAY :

Radiological findings of scurvy:

questions.text: A 3-year-old patient presented with difficulty in walking. On doing a clinical examination, it was observed that he has bow legs. An Xray was done of the patient which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Adequate supplies of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (1,25(OH)2D), calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, and normal body pH are essential for proper bone matrix mineralization.
  • Deficiency in any of these factors or severe systemic acidosis leads to defective bone mineralization.
  • Results in qualitative abnormalities, characterized by a reduced mineral-to-osteoid ratio.
  • Causes rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

Radiographic Changes in Children:

  • Abnormalities primarily observed at the growing ends of bones due to endochondral ossification.
  • Early stages show widening of the growth plate.
  • Severe changes result in "cupping" of the metaphysis with irregular mineralization.
  • Swelling around the ends of long bones leads to "rachitic rosary" at the anterior ends of the ribs.

Radiographic Changes in Adults:

  • At skeletal maturity, defective mineralization is seen as Looser zones, pathognomonic for osteomalacia.

Affected Areas:

  • Changes predominate around actively growing sites, particularly:
    • Knee
    • Wrist (especially ulna)
    • Anterior ends of middle ribs
    • Proximal femur
    • Distal tibia

MRI Findings:

  • May reveal abnormalities in physeal cartilage.

Deformities Resulting from Soft Bone:

  • The periphery of rachitic bone is soft, leading to:
    • Genu valgum or genu varum (knee deformities).
    • Deformities of the hips (coxa valga or coxa vara).
    • Bowing of long bones.
    • Harrison sulcus (indrawing of ribs at diaphragm insertion).
    • Protrusio acetabuli and triradiate pelvis deformity, which can complicate childbirth.

Option c: Fluorosis is a condition caused by excessive fluoride exposure, often leading to dental and skeletal changes.

  • Skeletal Fluorosis: In cases of skeletal fluorosis, X-rays may reveal increased bone density and changes in bone architecture, including thickening of the cortical bone and calcification of ligaments and tendons.
  • Radiographic Appearance: The presence of "ground glass" appearance in bones can be seen, indicating a loss of normal trabecular pattern, often associated with advanced fluorosis.

Option d: Acromegaly is a hormonal disorder caused by excess growth hormone, often due to a pituitary adenoma.

  • Skeletal Changes: X-rays may show enlarged bones, particularly of the hands, feet, and skull. Characteristic findings include thickened cortices and increased bone density.
  • Pituitary Imaging: MRI is the preferred modality for assessing pituitary adenomas. It typically reveals an enlarged pituitary gland with a mass effect, which may displace the optic chiasm.
  • Facial Changes: CT or MRI may demonstrate features such as an enlarged mandible, enlarged nasal bones, and changes in the soft tissue of the face, contributing to the characteristic appearance of acromegaly.

KEY TAKE AWAY :

questions.text: A 80 year old female patient came to the emergency department with a history of fall and severe back pain. On doing an Xray, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis is the most common metabolic bone disease, characterized by compromised bone strength, increasing the risk of fractures.

Fragility fractures due to osteoporosis pose significant challenges to global public health, particularly as the population ages.

Radiographic Features:

  • Osteoporosis is characterized by decreased radiodensity of bone.
  • Vertebral fractures are the most common type of osteoporotic fractures.

Vertebral Fractures:

  • Anterior and central portions of vertebrae are more susceptible to compression forces, leading to wedge or endplate fractures.
  • Fractures can be graded:
    • Mild (Grade 1): 20-25% change in shape.
    • Moderate (Grade 2): 26-40% change in shape.
    • Severe (Grade 3): >40% change in shape.

Skeletal Scintigraphy:

  • Increased uptake in regions of acute insufficiency fractures.
  • Characteristic "H pattern" (Honda sign)of radionuclide uptake may be seen when the sacrum is involved.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  1. Fish mouth vertebra are characteristic of osteoporosis.
  1. Bone Mineral Density (BMD) Classification:
  • Normal: BMD ≥ −1 SD of the young adult reference mean (peak bone mass).
  • Osteopenia: BMD between −1 and −2.5 SD below the young adult reference mean.
  • Osteoporosis: : BMD ≤ −2.5 SD below the young adult reference mean.
  • Severe osteoporosis: BMD ≤ −2.5 SD below the young adult reference mean in addition to Fracture

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old patient presented with a history of limping gait since 5 months. An Xray was done which is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), previously known as congenital dislocation of the hip (CDH), refers to abnormal development of the hip joint, specifically the relationship between the femoral head and the acetabulum.

Key risk factors for DDH include:

  1. Female gender(M
    ratio ~1:8)
  2. Firstborn baby
  3. Family history of DDH
  4. Breech presentation
  5. Oligohydramnios
  6. Metatarsus adductus
  7. Spina bifida

Imaging Assessment

For infants under 6 months, ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality as the proximal femoral epiphysis has not yet ossified significantly. This method allows for a dynamic assessment of hip stability through stress views.

In children older than 1 year, when the femoral head has ossified, a single anteroposterior (AP) radiograph is the most appropriate examination.

Key Imaging Findings

  • Ultrasound can show asymmetry in the femoral head ossification center, often appearing delayed on the affected side.
  • Assessment of the femoral head's position relative to the pelvis is crucial. Ideally, the femoral head should be centered in the inferomedial quadrant, defined by the intersection of the Hilgenreiner line and Perkin line.
  • Aninterruption of the Shenton line may also be visible, indicating potential dysplasia or dislocation.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Perthes disease


Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta


KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A young adolescent boy presented with history of pain and limping in the lower limbs. On examination he was found to have grade I obesity. An Xray was done. What is the expected finding in this case?
questions.solution:
Perthes Disease (Legg-Calvé-Perthes Disease)

Perthes disease is an idiopathic osteonecrosis of the femoral head in children. It's crucial to diagnose it as a condition of exclusion, ruling out other causes of osteonecrosis such as sickle cell disease, leukemia, corticosteroid use, and Gaucher disease.

Clinical Presentation

  • Common symptoms include atraumatic hip pain and limp.
  • Some children may have a history of minor trauma, but this is not always present.

Radiographic Findings

The disease is characterized by specific radiographic stages that reflect the severity of osteonecrosis and the duration of compromised blood supply:

Early Stage

  • No appreciable changes may be seen.
  • Joint effusion: Widening of the medial joint space.
  • Asymmetrical femoral epiphyseal size: The affected side may appear smaller.
  • Increased density of the femoral head epiphysis.
  • Blurring of the physeal plate.
  • Radiolucency of the proximal metaphysis.

Established Stage

  • Reduction in epiphyseal size and lucency in the femoral head.
  • Fragmentation and destruction of the femoral head may begin (Stage 2).

Late Stage (Burnt-Out Stage)

  • Deformity of the femoral head: Widening and flattening (known as coxa plana).
  • Proximal femoral neck deformity: Development of coxa magna.
  • 'Sagging rope sign': A thin sclerotic line across the femoral neck.
  • Possible lucencies extending inferolaterally into the femoral neck, which must be differentiated from infections or neoplasms.

Key MRI features to assess include:

  1. Deformity of the femoral head.
  2. Congruence: How well the femoral head fits within the acetabulum.
  3. Containment: The degree of lateral subluxation of the flattened femoral head.

Severe cases may lead to hinge abduction, where the femoral head pivots on the lateral acetabular rim rather than moving medially during hip abduction.

Nuclear Medicine

  • Bone Scintigraphy: Early stages may show reduced uptake in the femoral head due to decreased blood supply. In later stages, increased uptake may indicate repair processes and degenerative changes.

KEY TAKE AWAY :-

questions.text: A young infant was brought to OPD with history of fall. He was irritable on examination. On doing an examination multiple bruises were found. On doing a skeletal survey the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a group of congenital, non-sex-linked genetic disorders characterized by defective production of collagen type I.

This condition primarily affects connective tissues and bones, leading to notable clinical features.

Key Features

  • Osteoporosis and Fragility: Bones fracture easily, often with minimal or no trauma.
  • Blue Sclera: A distinct bluish tint to the sclera due to reduced collagen.
  • Dental Fragility: Increased susceptibility to dental issues.
  • Hearing Loss: Often due to inner ear abnormalities.

Plain radiography is the initial examination of choice for assessing OI. Key findings include:

Head, Neck, and Spine:

  • Basilar Invagination: Downward displacement of the skull base.
  • Wormian Bones: Extra bones in the sutures of the skull.
  • Kyphoscoliosis: Abnormal curvature of the spine.
  • Vertebral Compression Fractures: Resulting in height loss.
  • Codfish Vertebrae: Flattened vertebrae giving a "codfish" appearance.
  • Platyspondyly: Flattening of the vertebral bodies.

Chest:

  • Pectus Excavatum or Carinatum: Deformities of the chest wall.
  • Accordion Ribs: Ribs appear narrow and angled.

Pelvis:

  • Protrusio Acetabuli: Acetabular protrusion into the pelvis.
  • Coxa Vara: Deformity of the femoral neck.

General Findings:

  • Severe Osteoporosis: Generalized reduction in bone density.
  • Deformed, Gracile Bones: Overtubulated appearance of long bones.
  • Cortical Thinning: Thinner cortical bone layers.
  • Hyperplastic Callus Formation: Excessive healing tissue at fracture sites.
  • Popcorn Calcification: Scalloped radiolucent areas in metaphysis and epiphysis with sclerotic margins.
  • Zebra Stripe Sign: Sclerotic lines in long bones due to bisphosphonate treatment.
  • Pseudarthrosis Formation: Development of false joints at healing fracture sites.

CT scans can provide additional details, showing:

  • Wormian Bones: More clearly delineated than on X-rays.
  • Basilar Invagination: Better visualization of skull base deformities.
  • Otosclerosis: Abnormal bone growth in the ear, potentially leading to hearing loss.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A patient presented with hypermobility of the arms. On examination he had a large forehead and highly arched palate. An Xray is done which is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cleidocranial dysostosis (CCD), also known as cleidocranial dysplasia, is a rare skeletal dysplasia characterized by abnormal development of membranous bones.

It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Clinical Presentation

Patients with CCD may present with a variety of features, including:

  • Large Head: Notable for large fontanelles with delayed closure.
  • Broad Mandible: A wider-than-normal jaw.
  • Supernumerary Teeth: Extra teeth beyond the normal count.
  • High Arched Palate: A pronounced arch in the roof of the mouth.
  • Narrow and Bell-Shaped Thorax: May cause neonatal distress.
  • Excessively Mobile and Drooping Shoulders: Due to absent or hypoplastic clavicles.
  • Genu Valgum: Knock-knees.
  • Short Fingers: Often present as well.

Plain Radiograph

Skull:

  • Multiple Wormian Bones: Extra bones within the sutures of the skull.
  • Widened Sagittal Sutures and/or Fontanelles: Indicating delayed ossification.
  • Premature Fusion of the Coronal Suture: Can lead to brachycephaly (broad, short skull).
  • Frontal and/or Parietal Bossing: Prominent forehead or parietal regions.
  • Basilar Invagination: Potential for atlantoaxial impaction.
  • Persistent Metopic Suture
  • Supernumerary or Abnormal Teeth: Commonly observed in CCD.

Option c. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, leading to various systemic manifestations.

  • Skeletal Features: X-rays may show elongated bones, scoliosis, and pectus deformities (excavatum or carinatum)
  • Cardiovascular Findings: Echocardiography is essential for identifying aortic dilation or dissection and mitral valve prolapse, common in Marfan syndrome.
  • Ocular Abnormalities: MRI or CT may reveal lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) and other ocular changes associated with the syndrome.

Option D: Ehlers Danlos syndrome is characterized by generalized joint hypermobility, Hyperextensible skin, Fragile skin, Increased bruising, Velvety skin, Kyphoscoliosis

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Radiological findings of Cleidocranial dysplasia

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with deformed hands and difficulty in doing routine work. On doing an Xray the following image was obtained. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized

Early Radiographic Findings:

  1. Marginal Erosions: Important early finding, on the radial side of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints.
  2. Soft Tissue Swelling: Fusiform and periarticular swelling that indicates joint effusion, edema, and tenosynovitis.
  3. Osteoporosis: Initially appears juxta-articularly, later becoming generalized.
  4. Joint Space Narrowing: Symmetrical or concentric and uniform narrowing of the joint space.

Late Changes:

  1. Subchondral Cyst Formation: Occurs as the destruction of cartilage allows synovial fluid to enter the bone.
  2. Ulnar deviation of the MCP joints.
  3. Boutonnière, swan neck, and hitchhiker’s thumb deformities
  4. scapholunate dissociation and ulnar translocation.
  5. Ankylosis
  6. Pencil-in-Cup Deformity Typically associated with psoriatic arthropathy but also recognized in RA.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Difference between osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A young patient presented with backpain. The examination revealed stiffness of the lower back region. He was advised to undergo an Xray of the spine. It is shown below. What laboratorial test helps in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy characterized by inflammation leading to fusion (ankylosis) of the spine and sacroiliac (SI) joints, with potential involvement of large and small joints.

Plain Radiographic Findings

  • Sacroiliitis: Usually the first manifestation, typically symmetrical and bilateral.

Spine

  • Romanus Lesions: Small erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis (shiny corner sign).
  • Vertebral Body Squaring: Loss of normal vertebral contour.
  • Bamboo Spine: Characterized by diffuse syndesmophytic ankylosis.
  • Syndesmophytes: Ossification running parallel to the spine.
  • Dagger Spine: Linear ossification along the spine's central region, representing interspinous ligament ossification.
  • Ossification of Ligaments: Involvement of spinal ligaments, joints, and discs (with fatty marrow within the ossified disc seen best on MRI).
  • Apophyseal and Costovertebral Arthritis: Involvement leading to ankylosis.
  • Enthesitis pain at Bone spurs forming at sites of tendon and ligament attachment
  • Pseudoarthroses: May develop at fracture sites.

Positive Schober's Test: Less than 5cm increase in length with forward flexion

SERONEGATIVE ARTHRITIS

Anti CCP antibody test is used for rheumatoid arthritis .

questions.text: A patient presented with back pain and stiffness of the back. On further investigations, he was found to have ankylosing spondylitis. Among the following given options, he is at risk of developing which complication?
questions.solution: Complications of Ankylosing Spondylitis

questions.text: A patient presented with neck pain. He had reduced motility in the neck region. On doing an Xray, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis), also known as Forestier disease, is characterized by bony proliferation at sites of tendinous and ligamentous insertion, primarily affecting the spine in older individuals.

It is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging.

The ossifications are classically described in the spine as flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspect in at least three successive vertebral levels or four contiguous vertebrae

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Radiological features of DISH: -

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the legs. He underwent physiotherapy but the pain was not relieved. He observed that the pain was aggravated when he used to eat high protein food. On the basis of this the physician ordered a blood uric acid test. It was found to be elevated. He underwent an Xray which is shown below. What is being shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Gout is a crystal arthropathy caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in and around joints, leading to inflammation.

Clinical Presentation

  • Acute Gouty Arthritis:
    • Typically presents as a monoarticular joint that is red, inflamed, and swollen.
    • Most commonly affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint (podagra).
    • Often occurs during sleep and can evolve to involve multiple joint

Acute attack tends to occur after a large meal with foods rich in purines (red meat, seafood), trauma, surgery, dehydration, diuresis, or alcohol consumption (Alcohol metabolites compete for same excretion sites in kidney as uric acid leading to reduced uric acid secretion and subsequent buildup in blood)

Crystals are needle shaped and negatively birefringent under polarized light (yellow under parallel light, blue under perpendicular light )

KEY TAKE AWAY:

1. Marginal erosions

They occur at the bare area of the joint, where the bone is not covered by articular cartilage. They are typically seen in rheumatoid arthritis (MCP-joints) and psoriatic arthritis (DIP).

2. Subchondral erosions

They occur at the subchondral bone plate of the articular surfaces. They are a typical feature of erosive osteoarthritis. In erosive osteoarthritis the combination of central erosions and osteophytes results in a gullwing deformity.

3. Peri- or juxta articular erosions.

Gout erosions are a bit more eccentric juxta-articular located, where the joint capsule attaches to the bone. They are most often seen in the MTP1-joint. Rat bite erosions, aka Martel sign, are seen in gout and refer to punched out erosions with sclerotic and overhanging margins

4. Infection.

Destructive changes with cartilage loss and erosions

5. Pencil-in-cup deformity

In psoriatic arthritis the combination of marginal erosions and bone proliferation can result in a pencil-in-cup deformity.

choices.text: Geographic area of altered signal intensity

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presented with high grade fever and limping gait. He underwent an X Ray which showed reduced joint space which was suggestive of joint effusion. He underwent an MRI examination. Which of the following findings is not seen in MRI?
questions.solution:
Septic arthritis is an infection within a joint, leading to rapid chondrolysis and destructive arthropathy, typically presenting with severe pain and decreased range of motion.

Plain Radiograph

  • Early Stage: May appear normal in very early stages of infection.
  • Joint Effusion: Presence may be noted.
  • Juxta-Articular Osteoporosis: Due to hyperemia around the joint.
  • Joint Space Narrowing: Caused by cartilage destruction in the acute phase.
  • Subchondral Bone Destruction: Can occur on both sides of the joint.
  • Untreated Cases: May lead to reactive juxta-articular sclerosis or ankylosis in severe instances.

Ultrasound

  • Indications: Particularly useful for assessing superficial joints and in children.
  • Color Doppler: Increased peri-synovial vascularity may indicate inflammation.
  • Guided Aspiration: Useful for joint aspiration to obtain synovial fluid for analysis.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Morrey's criteria for septic arthritis.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the lower limbs. He underwent an Xray which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Melorheostosis is an uncommon mesenchymal dysplasia characterized by regions of sclerosing bone, exhibiting a distinctive "dripping wax" or "flowing candle wax" appearance on imaging.

Radiographic Patterns

  1. Classic: Periosteal cortical thickening and potential endosteal thickening.
    • Thick, undulating ridges of bone resembling molten wax, confined to sclerotomes and may flow across joints.
  2. Osteoma-like: Well-defined sclerotic lesions resembling osteomas.
  3. Myositis Ossificans-like: Ossification in soft tissues adjacent to bone.
  4. Osteopathia Striata-like: Striated patterns in bone density similar to osteopathia striata.
  5. Mixed: A combination of the above patterns may be observed.

KEY TAKE AWAY :

Melorheostosis shows, dripping wax appearance on x-ray.
